post.p: A matrix $A_{m \ times n}$ has $m$ rows and $n$ columns. Similarly, $A_{ij}$ represents the element on the $i$-th row and $j$-the column. Rows first, columns second.

A linear system is inconsistent if it has no solution, and consistent if it has either one solution or infinite solutions.
An elementary matrix is the result of applying an elementary row operation to the identity matrix.

ul.li: Interchange: Replacing one row with the other.
Multiplication: Each element in a row is multiplied by a non-zero $k$.
Addition: Replacing one row with the sum of itself and a multiplication of another.

post.p:
Gaussian elimination consists of applying these operations to the matrices (Formally, applying here means multiplying the matrix by the elementary matrix associated to that transformation) to turn the matrix into row echelon form, where we can tell whether it's consistent or not, and if it is, find its solution set.
A matrix is in row echelon form when:

ul.li: Every all-zero row is at the bottom of the matrix.
The leading coefficient of a non-zero row must be to the left of the one below it.
All entries below a leading coefficient are zero.

After performing Gaussian Elimination, if two matrices have the same row echelon form are said to be row equivalent (More formally, there exists a sequence of operations that transforms one to the other.

If, after Gaussian Elimination, a system has an equality like $c = k, \forall c, k \in R: c \neq k$, then the system is inconsistent.
If all the variables have a fixed value, the solution is unique. Otherwise, if there is at least one free variable, there are infinite solutions.
A vector, for the purposes of this course, is a matrix with a single column.

The vector $y = c_1v_1 + ... + c_nv_n$ is a linear combination of the vectors $\vflist{v}$ and weights $\vflist{c}$. The vector equation $x_1v_1, x_2v_2, ..., x_nv_n = y$ has the same solution as the system whose matrix is $[\vflist{v}]$.
The set of linear combinations that can be generated from the vectors $\vflist{v}$ is denoted $\Span{\vflist{v}}$.
The spanned set includes the zero vector, and every multiple of every vector $\vflist{v}$.
The vector equation $x_1v_1, x_2v_2, ..., x_nv_n = y$ is equivalent to the matrix equation $Ax = y$, where $A$ is the matrix of vectors $[\vflist{v}]$ and $x$ is the vector of weights. Asking whether $y \in \Span{\vflist{v}}$ is equivalent to asking whether $Ax = y$ is consistent.

A system that can be written as $Ax = 0$ is homogenous. The solution $x = 0$, which this type of system always has, is the trivial solution. The system has a non-trivial solution if it has at least one free variable.

A set of vectors $\vflist{v}$ are linearly independent if the vector equation $x_1v_1, x_2v_2, ..., x_nv_n = 0$ has only the trivial solution.
If the equation $Ax = 0$ has only the trivial solution, then the columns of $A$ are linearly independent.
A set of vectors is linearly dependent when at least one of the vectors is a multiple of any of the others.
If a set has more vectors than the number of entries in each vector, then it's linearly dependent.
If a set contains the zero vector, it's linearly dependent.

A transformation is a function $\fn{T}{R^n}{R^m}$.
A transformation is linear if:
Every matrix transformation $T(x) = Ax$ is linear.

Every linear transformation is of the form $T(x) = Ax$, and $A = [T(I_1) T(I_2) ... T(I_n)]$, where $I_i$ is the $i$-th column of the identity matrix.
T is surjective if the columns of its matrix span the codomain.
T is injective if the columns of its matrix are linearly independent.

A diagonal matrix has all zeros outside the diagonal.
The sum of two matrices is just the matrix of sums of corresponding entries.
The transposition of a matrix, $A^T$, is the result of flipping everything along the diagonal. Properties: $(A+B)^T = A^T + B^T$, $(AB)^T = B^TA^T$.

A matrix $A$ is invertible if $\exists C : AC = I$.
To find an inverse, perform Gaussian elimination on $[A I]$ until it becomes $[I A^-1]$. If that's not possible, it's not invertible.
If A is invertible, A is linearly independent, and $A^T$ is invertible.
The inverse of a linear transformation $T(x) = Ax$ is $S(x) = A^-1x$.
Factorization is a way of representing a matrix as the product of others.

Given $A_{m \times n}$, an LU factorization of $A$ is $A = LU$, where $L_{m \times m}$ is a lower triangular matrix with 1's on the diagonal and $U_{m \times n}$ is an echelon form of $A$. For example:
With this, an equation like $Ax = b$ becomes $LUx = b$. Let $Ux = y$, and we have two simpler equations to solve.
Reduce $A$ to its echelon form $U$. Then take an appropriately-sized identity matrix, apply the steps of Gaussian elimination backwards, and you end up with $L$.

A set of vectors $H$ is a subspace of $R_n$ if:
The zero vector is in $H$.
$\forall u, v \in H \rightarrow u + v \in H$.
$\forall u \in H, c \in R \rightarrow cu \in H$.
That is, a subspace is a set that goes through the origin where addition and scalar multiplication are closed.
The column space of a matrix $A_{m \times n}$ is the set $Col(A)$ of all linear combinations of the columns of $A$. $Col(A)$ is the same as $Span{A_1, ..., A_n}$ and if a subspace of $R^m$.
The null space of a matrix $A_{m \times n}$, $Nul(A)$, is the set of homogenous solutions to the equation $Ax = 0$. $Nul(A)$ is a subspace of $R_n$.
